Award.AwardTitle: Theoretical and Experimental Studies of the Magneto-Rayleigh-Taylor Instabilities
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is made in response to a proposal submitted to and reviewed under the NSF/DoE Partnership in Basic Plasma Science and Engineering joint solicitation NSF 08-589. The award provides funds to support undergraduate participation in the overall research effort, which is being funded separately by the DoE under contract Michigan (Science report #09ER55047).

This research is a controlled study of the Magneto-Rayleigh-Taylor instability (MRT) on thin foils, driven by the mega-ampere linear transformer driver (LTD) that was recently demonstrated in the Investigators' laboratory. This project involves theory, simulations, and experiments in which MRT scaling laws will be explored. This LTD is dedicated to physics experiments which are being designed and run by students, under close supervision of the faculty. Quite a few of the topics will be in unexplored territory; including the performance and characterization of the state-of-the-art LTD driving dynamical loads.

This research will include the development of phenomenology of MRT that is ubiquitous in magnetized target fusion, and equation-of-state studies using flyer plates or isentropic compression techniques. The proposed studies are at the forefront of high-energy density plasma physics. Foils might be necessary to achieve the required mass for high current x-ray sources, and the proposed study addresses the most fundamental physics issues.

The additional $5,000 per year funding from NSF will permit increased student involvement in this research. Specifically, additional funding is included for an undergraduate student to participate in this research. Funding for student travel to technical conferences (APS-DPP and IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science) is also included. This type of student travel experience is important for students to learn about other research and to begin to network with other scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Magneto-Rayleigh-Taylor instability (MRT) is important to magnetized target fusion, wire-array z-pinches, and equation-of-state studies using flyer plates or isentropic compression.  It is also important to the study of the crab nebula.  In a contemporary concept of magnetized target fusion, MRT on the surfaces of the liner is a major concern. With the support of this grant, the investigators performed MRT experiments on thin foils, driven by the mega-ampere linear transformer driver (LTD) facility completed in their laboratory (Fig. 1).  This is the first 1-MA LTD in the USA.  At least six PhD theses, during the performance period and ongoing, are devoted to LTD experiments and modeling. Two theses were completed whose authors are now regular staff members of the Naval Research Laboratory and Sandia National Laboratories. The students participated in summer internships at DoE laboratories. Students involved in the MRT project included 2 women, 2 Latinos, and 1 African American; all supported on Fellowships.

 

Dynamic plasma load experiments were performed. These experiments characterized MRT growth and plasma dynamics on planar-foil plasmas (Fig. 2). For these dynamic load experiments, the LTD was charged to ±70 kV to deliver up to 0.7 MA with 170 ns risetime into the foil load. The primary diagnostic for characterization of MRT consisted of a two-frame shadowgraphy system with a 100 ps frequency-doubled YAG laser. Calibrated B-dot loops measured the current flow to the load. The foil images from the 532 nm wavelength laser backlighting diagnostic with sub-nanosecond time resolution successfully captured MRT instability growth developing on both sides of the planar foil load (Fig. 3).

 

The Investigators have constructed a closed-form analytic solution for MRT on a finite plasma slab that is accelerated by an arbitrary combination of magnetic pressure and fluid pressure.  The magnetic field in different regions may assume arbitrary magnitude and direction tangential to the interfaces.  The temporal evolution of initial surface ripples was obtained. The effects of magnetic shear and feedthrough were analyzed. In addition to the analytic study, the UM group acquired the state-of-the-art capability of the simulation code, HYDRA, through student internships at the Sandia National Laboratories (Fig. 4). 

 

The combined experiments, theory, and simulation led to the interpretation of MRT data. The MRT development on the opposite surfaces of the ablated plasma slab was essentially decoupled, from the small values of the feedthrough factor. Instability growth rate measurements were made on each interface (Fig. 3), the trend displayed in these growth rates are consistent with the experimental data, regardless of the initial foil’s position which we adjusted to allow kinematic and dynamic control of MRT. Initial experiments on the seeding of MRT were performed toward the end of the performance period.  

 

The intellectual merit of this study includes: (A) one of the first experimental studies of MRT driven by the mega-ampere linear transformer driver [1], and (B) the most general MRT solution on a finite plasma slab that is applicable to laboratory and astrophysical plasmas, including arbitrary magnetic field (with magnetic shear) and arbitrary mix of kinetic and magnetic pressure in different regions [2,3].  The broader impact is that the insights obtained in this research may suggest viable ways toward MRT mitigation in the contemporary concept of magnetized liner inertial fusion, a hybrid between magnetic and inertial confinement that could significantly reduce the cost and complexity of achieving fusion gain.
